bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, February 11, 1900

div1.p: Lazear describes his journey and Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, February 11, 1900
div1.p:
We arrived here
yesterday morning after our
long complicated journey.
The steamer ride was
very pleasant for the
most part. We stopped
at Key West for four
hours and had a
chance to see the town.
The last night however
was rough and as
the boat was small
the rolling Kept us awake.
We have good rooms here
at the Hotel Mascotte
and I think we have the
best hotel here and not
expensive either - six dollars
a day for us all.

We were surprised to
find Havana a most
beautiful city, entirely unlike
anything we had ever seen
before. The color effects
are charming-wonderful
greens and pinks. There are
numerous fine gardens with
magnificent palms and flowers.

I have been very busy
reporting to various officials.
This morning I went to
the camp and was very
cordially received. The
medical corps is quartered
together in one long frame
one story building with
separate compartments.
It is on high ground overlooking the
sea. We all mess together. There are
five or six surgeons and the wife of
the chief surgeons. The camp is very
large, there are 1900 soldiers in all.

It is warmer than usual here just
now. Today it was 85°. Violent
exercise is out of the question. It is foolish
to do any walking. Things are surprisingly
expensive, even fruits cost more than in
Baltimore, oranges are five cents apiece.
Mabel is going out to camp with me
tomorrow to look at our quarters and
find what we shall need. They
furnish us beds and tables and as we
are to eat at the mess we shall not
need cooking and table utensils.

The baby is well and very much
interested in everything. Good milk is
not to be had so we have had to fall
back on condensed milk. I shall write
again in a day or two and tell how
things are going.
